import abc
from ..core.DtnQueue import DtnQueue
from ..core.DtnSegments import LtpCancelSessionSegment
from .DtnAbstractDuct import DtnAbstractDuct
import six


    [docs]@six.add_metaclass(abc.ABCMeta)
class DtnAbstractDuctLTP(DtnAbstractDuct):
    """ Abstract LTP duct. It is subclassed by both DtnOutductLTP and DtnInductLTP
        to provide the necessary functionality. This parent class provides some core
        functions and data structures such as:

            1) Requirement to re-implement ``initialize_ltp_session``, ``finalize_ltp_session``
               and ``ltp_session_manager``.
            2) A ``run_radio`` function that transmits data out of this duct. It has its own FIFO
               queue to model the below convergence layer queue of the actual radio
            3) A ``fail_manager`` that will redirect bundles that are not successfully delivered
               by the radio to the DTN node limbo for re-routers

        The core concept of LTP is a session, i.e. a process that will take care of sending a block
        of bundles from the outduct to induct. All re-tx required for a given block are handled by
        the same session. At any point in time, there can be any number of LTP sessions active
        since the underlying link can have long delays and therefore you do not want to wait for a session
        to end before starting another one.

        The LTP outduct creates a new session every time a new block of bundles is created. In contrast,
        an LTP induct creates a new session every time a new LTP Data Segment with a session_id not recognized
        is received. At both the outduct, a session ends when all the data has been sent. At the induct, a session
        ends when the RA for the last RS has been received.

        Critical to this process is having unique session ids. For this purpose, we utilize the hash function
        available in Python. Note that this could result in non-unique ids due to possible hash collisions. This
        is mitigated by using the hash of the hex of the memory address of the block if a hash collision is detected.
        If that method fails, then an exception is raised.
    """
    def __init__(self, env, name, parent, neighbor):
        # Call parent constructor
        super(DtnAbstractDuctLTP, self).__init__(env, name, parent, neighbor)

        # Input queues for each LTP session
        # NOTE: to know if a session is active, check if an ltp_queue exists
        self.ltp_queues = {}

        # Radio queue. Queue for radio below LTP
        self.radio_queue = DtnQueue(env)

        # Queue to store bundles that were not successfully sent by LTP
        # and thus must be sent to the node's limbo
        self.to_limbo = DtnQueue(env)

    def is_session(self, session_id):
        return session_id in self.ltp_queues

    def get_session_id(self, block):
        # First attempt
        sid = hash(block)
        if sid not in self.ltp_queues: return sid

        # Second attempt
        sid = hash(hex(id(block)))
        if sid not in self.ltp_queues: return sid

        # Raise an exception
        raise RuntimeError('Cannot create unique session_id at LTP duct {}'.format(self.name))

    @property
    def num_sessions(self):
        return len(self.ltp_queues)

    @property
    def ltp_sessions(self):
        return tuple(self.ltp_queues.keys())

    @property
    def transmit_mode(self):
        return 'fwd' if self.duct_type == 'outduct' else 'ack'

    def initialize(self, peer, *args, **kwargs):
        # Run the radio underneath the LTP sessions
        self.env.process(self.run_radio())

        # Run the fail manager that returns bundles that failed to be sent for
        # re-routers
        self.env.process(self.fail_manager())

        # Call parent initialization
        super(DtnAbstractDuctLTP, self).initialize(peer, **kwargs)

    @abc.abstractmethod
    def ltp_session_manager(self, *args, **kwargs):
        pass

    @abc.abstractmethod
    def initialize_ltp_session(self, *args, **kwargs):
        pass

    @abc.abstractmethod
    def finalize_ltp_session(self, *args, **kwargs):
        pass

    def fail_manager(self):
        while True:
            # Wait for bundles that were not successfully transmitted
            # by an LTP session
            bundle = yield from self.to_limbo.get()

            # Get the cid that needs to be excluded. This is not very neat, but
            # essentially reaches into the current DtnNeighborManager for this
            # neighbor and pulls the contact id
            cid = self.parent.queues[self.neighbor].current_cid

            # Send to node's limbo for re-routers
            self.parent.limbo(bundle, cid)

    def run_radio(self):
        while True:
            # Get the next segment to transmit
            segment = yield from self.radio_queue.get()

            # Get session id for this segment
            sid = segment.session_id

            # Check that the connection is in green state
            self.check_radio_active(sid)

            # Apply delay for radio to transmit entire segment
            yield self.env.timeout(segment.size / self.datarate)

            # Check that the connection is in green state
            self.check_radio_active(sid)

            # Transmit the message through the connection.
            # This is a non-blocking call since the bundle is out in transit
            self.conn.transmit(self.peer, segment, self.BER, direction=self.transmit_mode)

    def check_radio_active(self, session_id):
        # If the connection is in green state, nothing to worry
        if self.conn.active.is_green: return

        # Otherwise, create a Cancel Session Segment to close this LTP session
        cancel = LtpCancelSessionSegment(session_id)

        # Put this in the queue of segments for this session
        # Use expedited priority so that it gets executed immediately
        yield from self.ltp_queue[session_id].put(cancel, 0)
